quiz.question: According to economic signaling theory, consumers may perceive the frequency with which an unfamiliar brand is advertised as a cue that the brand is of high quality. [...] Which of the following best describes the purpose of the sentence in lines 10–15?

options.A: To show that economic signaling theory fails to explain a finding
options.B: To introduce a distinction not accounted for by economic signaling theory
options.C: To account for an exception to a generalization suggested by Marquardt and McGann
options.D: To explain why Marquardt and McGann’s research was conducted
options.E: To offer an explanation for an observation reported by Marquardt and McGann

quiz.question: The primary purpose of the passage is to

options.A: present findings that contradict one explanation for the effects of a particular advertising practice
options.B: argue that theoretical explanations about the effects of a particular advertising practice are of limited value without empirical evidence
options.C: discuss how and why particular advertising practices may affect consumers’ perceptions
options.D: contrast the research methods used in two different studies of a particular advertising practice
options.E: explain why a finding about consumer responses to a particular advertising practice was unexpected

quiz.question: Kirmani’s research, as described in the passage, suggests which of the following regarding consumers’ expectations about the quality of advertised products?

options.A: Those expectations are likely to be highest if a manufacturer runs both black-and-white and color advertisements for the same product.
options.B: Those expectations can be shaped by the presence of color in an advertisement as well as by the frequency with which an advertisement appears.
options.C: Those expectations are usually high for frequently advertised new brands but not for frequently advertised familiar brands.
options.D: Those expectations are likely to be higher for products whose black-and-white advertisements are often repeated than for those whose color advertisements are less often repeated.
options.E: Those expectations are less definitively shaped by the manufacturer’s advertisements than by information that consumers gather from other sources.

quiz.question: Kirmani’s third study, as described in the passage, suggests which of the following conclusions about a black-and-white advertisement?

options.A: It can be repeated more frequently than a comparable color advertisement could before consumers begin to suspect low manufacturer confidence in the quality of the advertised product.
options.B: It will have the greatest impact on consumers’ perceptions of the quality of the advertised product if it appears during periods when a color version of the same advertisement is also being used.
options.C: It will attract more attention from readers of the print publication in which it appears if it is used only a few times.
options.D: It may be perceived by some consumers as more expensive than a comparable color advertisement.
options.E: It is likely to be perceived by consumers as a sign of higher manufacturer confidence in the quality of the advertised product than a comparable color advertisement would be.

quiz.question: The passage suggests that Kirmani would be most likely to agree with which of the following statements about consumers’ perceptions of the relationship between the frequency with which a product is advertised and the product’s quality?

options.A: Consumers’ perceptions about the frequency with which an advertisement appears are their primary consideration when evaluating an advertisement’s claims about product quality.
options.B: Because most consumers do not notice the frequency of advertisement, it has little impact on most consumers’ expectations regarding product quality.
options.C: Consumers perceive frequency of advertisement as a signal about product quality only when the advertisement is for a product that is newly on the market.
options.D: The frequency of advertisement is not always perceived by consumers to indicate that manufacturers are highly confident about their products’ quality.
options.E: Consumers who try a new product that has been frequently advertised are likely to perceive the advertisement’s frequency as having been an accurate indicator of the product’s quality.

quiz.question: The main purpose of the passage is to

options.A: propose an experiment
options.B: analyze a function
options.C: refute an argument
options.D: explain a contradiction
options.E: simulate a process

quiz.question: Which of the following is most consistent with Searle’s reasoning as presented in the passage?

options.A: Meaning and content cannot be reduced to algorithms.
options.B: The process of digestion can be simulated mechanically, but not on a computer.
options.C: Simulated thoughts and real thoughts are essentially similar because they are composed primarily of information.
options.D: A computer can use “causal powers” similar to those of the human brain when processing information.
options.E: Computer simulations of the world can achieve the complexity of the brain’s representations of the world.

quiz.question: The author of the passage would be most likely to agree with which of the following statements about the simulation of organ functions?

options.A: An artificial device that achieves the functions of the stomach could be considered a valid model of the stomach.
options.B: Computer simulations of the brain are best used to crack the brain’s codes of meaning and content.
options.C: Computer simulations of the brain challenge ideas that are fundamental to psychology and neuroscience.
options.D: Because the brain and the stomach both act as processors, they can best be simulated by mechanical devices.
options.E: The computer’s limitations in simulating digestion suggest equal limitations in computer simulated thinking.

quiz.question: It can be inferred that the author of the passage believes that Searle’s argument is flawed by its failure to

options.A: distinguish between syntactic and semantic operations
options.B: explain adequately how people, unlike computers, are able to understand meaning
options.C: provide concrete examples illustrating its claims about thinking
options.D: understand how computers use algorithms to process information
options.E: decipher the code that is transmitted from neuron to neuron in the brain

quiz.question: From the passage, it can be inferred that the author would agree with Searle on which of the following points?

options.A: Computers operate by following algorithms.
options.B: The human brain can never fully understand its own functions.
options.C: The comparison of the brain to a machine is overly simplistic.
options.D: The most accurate models of physical processes are computer simulations.
options.E: Human thought and computer-simulated thought involve similar processes of representation.

quiz.question: Which of the following most accurately represents Searle’s criticism of the brain-as-computer metaphor, as that criticism is described in the passage?

options.A: The metaphor is not experimentally verifiable.
options.B: The metaphor does not take into account the unique powers of the brain.
options.C: The metaphor suggests that a brain’s functions can be simulated as easily as those of a stomach.
options.D: The metaphor suggests that a computer can simulate the workings of the mind by using the codes of neural transmission.
options.E: The metaphor is unhelpful because both the brain and the computer process information.

quiz.question: The primary purpose of the passage is to

options.A: explain why women reformers of the Progressive Era failed to achieve their goals
options.B: discuss the origins of child labor laws in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries
options.C: compare the living conditions of working-class and middle-class women in the Progressive Era
options.D: discuss an oversight on the part of women reformers of the Progressive Era
options.E: revise a traditional view of the role played by women reformers in enacting Progressive Era reforms

quiz.question: The view mentioned in line 17 of the passage refers to which of the following?

options.A: Women’s grassroots activism and their vision of a new civic consciousness lay at the heart of social reform in the United States throughout the Progressive Era
options.B: Some working-class mothers’ resistance to the enforcement of child labor laws
options.C: Reformers’ belief that child labor and industrial home work should be abolished
options.D: Reformers’ opinions about how working-class families raised their children
options.E: Working-class families’ fears about the adverse consequences that child labor laws would have on their ability to earn an adequate living

quiz.question: The author of the passage mentions the observations of women historians (lines 15–17) most probably in order to

options.A: provide support for an assertion made in the preceding sentence (lines 10–12)
options.B: raise a question that is answered in the last sentence of the passage (lines 27–32)
options.C: introduce an opinion that challenges a statement made in the first sentence of the passage
options.D: offer an alternative view to the one attributed in the passage to working-class mothers
options.E: point out a contradiction inherent in the traditional view of child labor reform as it is presented in the passage

quiz.question: The passage suggests that which of the following was a reason for the difference of opinion between working-class mothers and women reformers on the issue of child labor?

options.A: Reformers’ belief that industrial home work was preferable to child labor outside the home
options.B: Reformers’ belief that child labor laws should pertain to working conditions but not to pay
options.C: Working-class mothers’ resentment at reformers’ attempts to interfere with their parenting
options.D: Working-class mothers’ belief that child labor was an inhumane practice
options.E: Working-class families’ need for every employable member of their families to earn money

quiz.question: The author of the passage asserts which of the following about women reformers who tried to abolish child labor?

options.A: They alienated working-class mothers by attempting to enlist them in agitating for progressive causes.
options.B: They underestimated the prevalence of child labor among the working classes.
options.C: They were correct in their conviction that child labor was deplorable but shortsighted about the impact of child labor legislation on working-class families.
options.D: They were aggressive in their attempts to enforce child labor legislation, but were unable to prevent working-class families from circumventing them.
options.E: They were prevented by their nearly total disenfranchisement from making significant progress in child labor reform.

quiz.question: According to the passage, one of the most striking achievements of white middle-class women reformers during the Progressive Era was

options.A: gaining the right to vote in school elections
options.B: mobilizing working-class women in the fight against child labor
options.C: uniting women of different classes in grassroots activism
options.D: improving the economic conditions of working class families
options.E: improving women’s and children’s working conditions

quiz.question: Vasquez-Morrell Assurance specializes in insuring manufacturers. [...] Which of the following, if true, most seriously calls into question the consultants’ criterion for selecting the staff to be laid off?

options.A: If the time that Vasquez-Morrell takes to settle claims increases significantly, it could lose business to other insurers.
options.B: Supervisors at Vasquez-Morrell tend to assign the most complex claims to the most capable adjusters.
options.C: At Vasquez-Morrell, no insurance payments are made until a claims adjuster has reached a final determination on the claim.
options.D: There are no positions at Vasquez-Morrell to which staff currently employed as claims adjusters could be reassigned.
options.E: The premiums that Vasquez-Morrell currently charges are no higher than those charged for similar coverage by competitors.

quiz.question: Prolonged spells of hot, dry weather at the end of the grape-growing season typically reduce a vineyard’s yield [...] Nonetheless, in regions where wine producers generally grow their own grapes, analysts typically expect a long, hot, dry spell late in the growing season to result in increased revenues for local wine producers. Which of the following, if true, does most to justify the analysts’ expectation?

options.A: The lower a vineyard’s yield, the less labor is required to harvest the grapes.
options.B: Long, hot, dry spells at the beginning of the grape-growing season are rare, but they can have a devastating effect on a vineyard’s yield.
options.C: Grapes grown for wine production are typically made into wine at or near the vineyard in which they were grown.
options.D: When hot, dry spells are followed by heavy rains, the rains frequently destroy grape crops.
options.E: Grapes that have matured in hot, dry weather make significantly better wine than ordinary grapes.

quiz.question: In the past, most children who went sledding in the winter snow in Verland used wooden sleds with runners and steering bars. [...] The concern that plastic sleds are more dangerous is clearly borne out by the fact that the number of children injured while sledding was much higher last winter than it was 10 years ago. Which of the following, if true in Verland, most seriously undermines the force of the evidence cited?

options.A: A few children still use traditional wooden sleds.
options.B: Very few children wear any kind of protective gear, such as helmets, while sledding.
options.C: Plastic sleds can be used in a much wider variety of snow conditions than wooden sleds can.
options.D: Most sledding injuries occur when a sled collides with a tree, a rock, or another sled.
options.E: Because the traditional wooden sleds can carry more than one rider, an accident involving a wooden sled can result in several children being injured.

quiz.question: Metal rings recently excavated from seventh-century settlements in the western part of Mexico were made using the same metallurgical techniques as those used by Ecuadorian artisans [...] Which of the following would it be most useful to establish in order to evaluate the archaeologists’ hypothesis?

options.A: Whether metal objects were traded from Ecuador to western Mexico during the seventh century
options.B: Whether travel between western Mexico and Ecuador in the seventh century would have been primarily by land or by sea
options.C: Whether artisans from western Mexico could have learned complex metallurgical techniques from their Ecuadorian counterparts without actually leaving western Mexico
options.D: Whether metal tools were used in the seventh century settlements in western Mexico
options.E: Whether any of the techniques used in the manufacture of the metal rings found in western Mexico are still practiced among artisans in Ecuador today

quiz.question: Following several years of declining advertising sales, the Greenville Times reorganized its advertising sales force. [...] In assessing whether the improvement in advertising sales can properly be attributed to the reorganization, it would be most helpful to find out which of the following?

options.A: What proportion of the total revenue of the Greenville Times is generated by advertising sales?
options.B: Has the circulation of the Greenville Times increased substantially in the last two years?
options.C: Among all the types of industry and retailing that use the Greenville Times as an advertising vehicle, which type accounts for the largest proportion of the newspaper’s advertising sales?
options.D: Do any clients of the sales representatives of the Greenville Times have a standing order with the Times for a fixed amount of advertising per month?
options.E: Among the advertisers in the Greenville Times, are there more types of retail business or more types of industrial business?

quiz.question: Motorists in a certain country frequently complain that traffic congestion is much worse now than it was 20 years ago. [...] Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.A: Most automobile travel is local, and the networks of roads and streets in the country’s settled areas have changed little over the last 20 years.
options.B: Gasoline prices are high, and miles traveled per car per year have not changed much over the last 20 years.
options.C: The country’s urban centers have well-developed public transit systems that carry most of the people who commute into those centers.
options.D: The average age of automobiles registered in the country is lower now than it was 20 years ago.
options.E: Radio stations have long been broadcasting regular traffic reports that inform motorists about traffic congestion.

quiz.question: The percentage of households with an annual income of more than $40,000 is higher in Merton County than in any other county. However, the percentage of households with an annual income of $60,000 or more is higher in Sommer County. If the statements above are true, which of the following must also be true?

options.A: The percentage of households with an annual income of $80,000 is higher in Sommer County than in Merton County.
options.B: Merton County has the second highest percentage of households with an annual income of $60,000 or more.
options.C: Some households in Merton County have an annual income between $40,000 and $60,000.
options.D: The number of households with an annual income of more than $40,000 is greater in Merton County than in Sommer County.
options.E: Average annual household income is higher in Sommer County than in Merton County.

quiz.question: Tiger beetles are such fast runners that they can capture virtually any nonflying insect. [...] Which of the following, if discovered in experiments using artificially moved prey insects, would support one of the two hypotheses and undermine the other?

options.A: When a prey insect is moved directly toward a beetle that has been chasing it, the beetle immediately stops and runs away without its usual intermittent stopping.
options.B: In pursuing a swerving insect, a beetle alters its course while running and its pauses become more frequent as the chase progresses.
options.C: In pursuing a moving insect, a beetle usually responds immediately to changes in the insect’s direction, and it pauses equally frequently whether the chase is up or down an incline.
options.D: If, when a beetle pauses, it has not gained on the insect it is pursuing, the beetle generally ends its pursuit.
options.E: The faster a beetle pursues an insect fleeing directly away from it, the more frequently the beetle stops.

quiz.question: Guillemots are birds of Arctic regions. [...] Therefore, if the warming continues, the guillemots’ range will probably be enlarged by being extended northward along the coast. Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.A: Even if the warming trend continues, there will still be years in which guillemot chicks are killed by an unusually early snow.
options.B: If the Arctic warming continues, guillemots’ current predators are likely to succeed in extending their own range farther north.
options.C: Guillemots nest in coastal areas, where temperatures are generally higher than in inland areas.
options.D: If the Arctic warming continues, much of the thin ice in the southern Arctic will disappear.
options.E: The fish that guillemots eat are currently preyed on by a wider variety of predators in the southernmost Arctic regions than they are farther north.

quiz.question: Some batches of polio vaccine used around 1960 were contaminated with SV40 [...] This claim is not undercut by the fact that a very careful survey made in the 1960s of people who had received the contaminated vaccine found no elevated incidence of any cancer, since ____________.

options.A: most cases of mesothelioma are caused by exposure to asbestos
options.B: in some countries, there was no contamination of the vaccine
options.C: SV40 is widely used in laboratories to produce cancers in animals
options.D: mesotheliomas take several decades to develop
options.E: mesothelioma was somewhat less common in 1960 than it is now

quiz.question: Gortland has long been narrowly self-sufficient in both grain and meat. [...] Therefore, since per capita income continues to rise, whereas domestic grain production will not increase, Gortland will soon have to import either grain or meat or both. Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?

options.A: The total acreage devoted to grain production in Gortland will soon decrease.
options.B: Importing either grain or meat will not result in a significantly higher percentage of Gortlanders’ incomes being spent on food than is currently the case.
options.C: The per capita consumption of meat in Gortland is increasing at roughly the same rate across all income levels.
options.D: The per capita income of meat producers in Gortland is rising faster than the per capita income of grain producers.
options.E: People in Gortland who increase their consumption of meat will not radically decrease their consumption of grain.

quiz.question: The Hazelton coal-processing plant is a major employer in the Hazelton area [...] In order to prevent a major increase in local unemployment, the Hazelton government is considering granting the plant’s request. Which of the following would be most important for the Hazelton government to determine before deciding whether to grant the plant’s request?

options.A: Whether the company that owns the plant would open a new plant in another area if the present plant were closed
options.B: Whether the plant would employ far fewer workers when updated than it does now
options.C: Whether the level of pollutants presently being emitted by the plant is high enough to constitute a health hazard for local residents
options.D: Whether the majority of the coal processed by the plant is sold outside the Hazelton area
options.E: Whether the plant would be able to process more coal when updated than it does now

quiz.question: A physically active lifestyle has been shown to help increase longevity. [...] Clearly, this circumstance explains the long lives of people in Wistar. Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.A: In Bellaria all medical expenses are paid by the government, so that personal income does not affect the quality of health care a person receives.
options.B: The Wistar region is one of Bellaria’s least populated regions.
options.C: Many people who live in the Wistar region have moved there in middle age or upon retirement.
options.D: The many opportunities for hiking, skiing, and other outdoor activities that Wistar’s mountains offer make it a favorite destination for vacationing Bellarians.
options.E: Per capita spending on recreational activities is no higher in Wistar than it is in other regions of Bellaria.

quiz.question: Cheever College offers several online courses via remote computer connection [...] If the statements above are true, which of the following must also be true of Cheever College?

options.A: Among students who did not withdraw, students enrolled in online courses got higher grades, on average, than students enrolled in classroom-based courses.
options.B: The number of students enrolled per course at the start of the school term is much higher, on average, for the online courses than for the classroom-based courses.
options.C: There are no students who take both an online and a classroom-based course in the same school term.
options.D: Among Cheever College students with the best grades, a significant majority take online, rather than classroom-based, courses.
options.E: Courses offered online tend to deal with subject matter that is less challenging than that of classroom-based courses.

quiz.question: For years the beautiful Renaissance buildings in Palitito have been damaged by exhaust from the many tour buses [...] The city has now provided parking that accommodates a third of the tour buses, so damage to Palitito’s buildings from the buses’ exhaust will diminish significantly. Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the argument?

options.A: The exhaust from Palitito’s few automobiles is not a significant threat to Palitito’s buildings.
options.B: Palitito’s Renaissance buildings are not threatened by pollution other than engine exhaust.
options.C: Tour buses typically spend less than one-quarter of the time they are in Palitito transporting passengers from one site to another.
options.D: More tourists come to Palitito by tour bus than by any other single means of transportation.
options.E: Some of the tour buses that are unable to find parking drive around Palitito while their passengers are visiting a site.

quiz.question: During the 1980s and 1990s, the annual number of people who visited the Sordellian Mountains increased continually [...] Which of the following, if true in the Sordellian Mountains during the 1980s and 1990s, most helps to explain the decrease?

options.A: Avalanches were most likely to happen when a large new snowfall covered an older layer of snow.
options.B: Avalanches destroyed at least some buildings in the Sordellian Mountains in every year.
options.C: People planning new ski slopes and other resort facilities used increasingly accurate information about which locations are likely to be in the path of avalanches.
options.D: The average length of stay for people visiting the Sordellian Mountains increased slightly.
options.E: Construction of new ski resorts often led to the clearing of wooded areas that had helped to prevent avalanches.

quiz.question: A year ago, Dietz Foods launched a yearlong advertising campaign for its canned tuna. [...] Clearly, therefore, the campaign did nothing to further Dietz’s economic interests. Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.A: Sales of canned tuna account for a relatively small percentage of Dietz Foods’ profits.
options.B: Most of the people who bought Dietz’s canned tuna for the first time as a result of the campaign were already loyal customers of other Dietz products.
options.C: A less expensive advertising campaign would have brought in significantly fewer new customers for Dietz’s canned tuna than did the campaign Dietz Foods launched last year.
options.D: Dietz made money on sales of canned tuna last year.
options.E: In each of the past five years, there was a steep, industry-wide decline in sales of canned tuna.

quiz.question: Unlike the buildings in Mesopotamian cities, which were arranged haphazardly, the same basic plan was followed for all cities of the Indus Valley: with houses laid out on a north-south, east-west grid, and houses and walls were built of standard-size bricks.

options.C: that for every dollar spent on controlled small scale burning, forest thinning, and the training of fire-management personnel saves seven dollars on not having to extinguish

quiz.question: The results of two recent unrelated studies support the idea that dolphins may share certain cognitive abilities with humans and great apes; the studies indicate dolphins as capable of recognizing themselves in mirrors—an ability that is often considered a sign of self-awareness—and to grasp spontaneously the mood or intention of humans.

options.A: dolphins as capable of recognizing themselves in mirrors—an ability that is often considered a sign of self-awareness—and to grasp spontaneously

quiz.question: According to scholars, the earliest writing was probably not a direct rendering of speech, but was more likely to begin as a separate and distinct symbolic system of communication, and only later merged with spoken language.

options.A: was more likely to begin as
options.B: more than likely began as
options.C: more than likely beginning from
options.D: it was more than likely begun from
options.E: it was more likely that it began

options.A: with students’ objections to particular activities, so long as the groups they give money to will be

options.D: from students who object to particular activities, so long as the groups given money are

quiz.question: Despite the increasing number of women graduating from law school and passing bar examinations, the proportion of judges and partners at major law firms who are women have not risen to a comparable extent.

options.A: the proportion of judges and partners at major law firms who are women have not risen to a comparable extent
options.B: the proportion of women judges and partners at major law firms have not risen comparably
options.C: the proportion of judges and partners at major law firms who are women has not risen comparably
options.D: yet the proportion of women judges and partners at major law firms has not risen to a comparable extent
options.E: yet the proportion of judges and partners at major law firms who are women has not risen comparably

quiz.question: Seldom more than 40 feet wide and 12 feet deep, but it ran 363 miles across the rugged wilderness of upstate New York, the Erie Canal connected the Hudson River at Albany to the Great Lakes at Buffalo, providing the port of New York City with a direct water link to the heartland of the North American continent.

options.A: Seldom more than 40 feet wide and 12 feet deep, but it ran 363 miles across the rugged wilderness of upstate New York, the Erie Canal connected
options.B: Seldom more than 40 feet wide or 12 feet deep but running 363 miles across the rugged wilderness of upstate New York, the Erie Canal connected

options.A: the Supreme Court declared a minimum wage for women and children in the District of Columbia as unconstitutional, and
options.B: the Supreme Court declared as unconstitutional a minimum wage for women and children in the District of Columbia, and
options.C: the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a minimum wage for women and children in the District of Columbia,
